avalancheActivity.comment:
The avalanche danger is moderate above 2000 metres and low below.
At high altitudes, avalanches can be triggered by individual winter sports enthusiasts in areas adjacent to the ridgeline, crest or summit. Most of the avalanche prone locations are in the north and east sectors. The risk of falling outweighs the risk of burial away from terrain traps and there is usually more danger from stones than from snow. The avalanche prone locations are often covered in snow and therefore not always recognisable.
avalancheActivity.highlights: New fallen snow covers old avalanche prone locations such as drifting snow clods and stones.

snowpackStructure.comment:
New fallen snow covers older drift snow and stones
The old snowpack consists of layers of faceted crystals, deep rime and melt-freeze crusts and has little tendency to spread.
Overall, there is little snow.

tendency.highlights: Fresh wind slab forms at the weekend. The avalanche risk increases slightly.

weatherForecast.comment: On Friday it will snow from dense clouds, 5 cm to 10 cm will fall with little wind. At 2000 m -3 to -8 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment:
The avalanche danger is moderate above 2000 metres and low below.
Small (occasionally medium) snow slabs can be triggered by individual winter sports enthusiasts in some places, adjacent to the ridgeline and distant from ridgelines behind terrain edges in the north-west, over east to south-facing terrain. Wind slabs have also accumulated in gullies and bowls. Some of the windslab snow will be covered with snow during the daytime changes, making it difficult to recognise. In addition to the risk of burial, attention must be paid to the risk of being swept away and falling. There are also still many rocks lurking.
avalancheActivity.highlights: South foehn and north-westerly winds formed prone to triggering wind slab.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Wind and snowfall form(ed) wind slabs. The weak layer for a snow slab can be the last snow to fall, surface hoar as well as faceted crystals above/below the uppermost crust.
The old snowpack consists of layers of faceted crystals, deep rime and melt-freeze crusts and has little tendency to break up.
The amount of snow is well below average.

tendency.highlights: Wind and new fallen snow will form fresh wind slabs at the weekend. The avalanche risk increases slightly.

weatherForecast.comment:
During the night to Friday it will snow about 5 cm. The wind will be moderate to brisk, mainly from the south.
On Friday it will snow from dense clouds. Most of the new fallen snow (about 10 cm) will fall in the morning. The southerly wind will gradually weaken. Visibility will improve somewhat in the afternoon and the snowfall will subside. Hardly any wind. At 2000 m -3 to -8 degrees, at 3000 m -9 to -14 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment:
The avalanche danger is moderate above 2000 metres and low below.
Small (occasionally medium) snow slabs can be triggered by individual winter sports enthusiasts in some places, area adjacent to the ridgeline and distant from ridgelines behind terrain edges in the extended northern sector. Fresh, prone-to-triggering wind slabs can also accumulate in gullies and bowls.  In addition to the risk of burial, attention must be paid to the risk of being swept away and falling. There are also still many rocks lurking.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Wind and snowfall form fresh wind slabs. The weak layer for a snow slab can be the last snow to fall, surface hoar as well as faceted crystals above/below the uppermost crust.
The old snowpack is made up of layers of faceted crystals, deep rime and melt-freeze crusts and has little tendency to break up.
The amount of snow is well below average.

tendency.highlights: Wind and new fallen snow will form fresh wind slabs at the weekend. The avalanche risk increases slightly.

weatherForecast.comment:
It snows in the night to Friday. Around 10 cm will fall along the northern Alps. It will become milder and the snowfall level will rise to around 1400 metres on the northern edge of the Alps. The wind will be moderate to brisk, mainly from the south.
On Friday it will snow (5 cm to 10 cm) from dense clouds.  The southerly winds will gradually weaken and temperatures will also drop slightly during the daytime changes. At 2000 m -2 to -6 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is low, isolated danger areas due to fresh snowdrift accumulations can be found behind the edges of the terrain adjacent to the ridgeline, crest or summit.

snowpackStructure.comment: Little snow and rain in the morning up to around 1400 metres. There are often only a few centimetres of snow / wind slab on the meadows or on a thin crust of harsh snow.

weatherForecast.comment: On Friday, it will snow lightly to moderately heavily at times. It will briefly become milder and the snowfall level will be around 1400 metres in the morning before it cools down again. At 1500 m +1 to -2 degrees. Weak to moderate southerly winds in the morning.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is low. However, small avalanches (soft and loose) or slabs may be triggered, especially in the area adjacent to the ridgeline, crest or summit.
avalancheActivity.highlights: New fallen snow without significant wind

snowpackStructure.comment: Little snow. There are often only a few centimetres of snow / wind slab on the meadows or on a thin crust of harsh snow.

tendency.highlights: Fresh wind slab forms at the weekend. The avalanche risk increases slightly.

weatherForecast.comment: It will snow from dense clouds on Friday. It will fall 10 to 15 cm with little wind. At 2000 m -3 to -8 degrees.

ALBINA.generalHeadline: Fresh and older wind slab, partly covered with snow.
